{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3565141,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T02:56:24.757Z","cooked":"

I need to make a trajectory where a robot stops at a specific point, runs a command, and then continues with the trajectory.

Is the only way to do so - splitting it in multiple path, and combining the path into sequential group in PathPlanner Auto?

The parallel commands made into triggers and binded to Event Markers work fine (meaning if I need a command that would start at specific point, but the bot would continue driving as the command is going, like ElevatorUp, starting at certain point of a trajectory).

By the way - at first we tried simply using Named Commands with the same names as defined in PathPlanner trajectory and that did not work (commands did not run).
then we binded them to triggers, and that did work.

here is the code in question:

github.com

FRC999/2025Competition/blob/6adf9e20aa3c3becf80b8aa109f8265581768c25/C2025_release/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java#L172


      
    
          
  1. 
          
  2. // PathPlanner AutoBuilder Test
    3. 
          
  3. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest1", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Blu-BargeToReef11",true, false));
    4. 
          
  4. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest2", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Blu-Reef11ToCoralTop",false,false));
    5. 
          
  5. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest3", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Blu-CoralTopToReef10",false,false));
    6. 
          
  6. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest4", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Blu-CoralTopToReef9",false,false));
    7. 
          
  7. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest5", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Blu-Reef10ToCoralTop",false,false));
    8. 
          
  8. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest6", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Red-BargetoReef11",true,false));
    9. 
          
  9. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest7", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Red-Reef11toCoralBottom",false,false));
    10. 
          
  10. // NamedCommands.registerCommand("ppTest8", runTrajectoryPathPlannerWithForceResetOfStartingPose("Red-CoralBottomtoReef10",false,false));
    11. 
          
  11. NamedCommands.registerCommand("AutoPPElevatorUpToFour", new AutoPPElevatorUpToFour());
    12. 
          
  12. NamedCommands.registerCommand("AutoPPElevatorAllTheWayDown", new AutoPPElevatorAllTheWayDown());
    13. 
          
  13. NamedCommands.registerCommand("AutoPPIntakeCoral", new AutoPPIntakeCoral());
    14. 
          
  14. NamedCommands.registerCommand("AutoPPCoralPlaceOnFour", new AutoPPCoralPlaceOnFour());
    15. 
          
  15. NamedCommands.registerCommand("AlexTest", new PrintCommand("****Test 0"));
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17. new EventTrigger("AutoPPElevatorUpToFour").onTrue(new AutoPPElevatorUpToFour());
    18. 
          
  18. new EventTrigger("AutoPPElevatorAllTheWayDown").onTrue(new AutoPPElevatorAllTheWayDown());
    19. 
          
  19. new EventTrigger("AutoPPIntakeCoral").onTrue(new AutoPPIntakeCoral());
    20. 
          
  20. new EventTrigger("AutoPPCoralPlaceOnFour").onTrue(new AutoPPCoralPlaceOnFour());
    21. 
          
  21.

So, when we simply had lines 172…176, it did not work. When we added lines 178…181, it worked. But we’re trying to do some of these commands in a way that we would want robot to stop driving, do a command and them continue again, while other commands we want to run parallel to auto-driving.

So, I guess my questions are:

  1. Am I correct that triggers are required for the commands to actually run with markers?
  2. Am I correct that the only way to run commands in a middle of a large trajectory and have the robot stopped, the trajectory needs to be divided into parts that are combined via PP Auto screen?

To answer your first question, no you can run named commands without triggers.I think your issue is that you do not have an autos folder listed under src main deploy pathplanner. You do have paths, but then in pathplanner you have to create autos, by chaining the paths together if that makes sense. Then for namedcommands, you call them within the autos and both of these things are handled by the path planner app itself, as long as you still call registers command for the commands you want. The answer to your second question is YES.

So the event markers have their own name that isn’t the named commands in the GUI. To have your named commands run at a certain event marker, you need to click the plus sign at bottom of event marker to add a command.

I don’t know what would happen if you add a wait command here or parallel wait with another command. Try and see

When you said - I do not have autofs folder listed - where should I list them?

As I mentioned - running a path itself works fine (for driving). The commands are not triggered, though, if I do not describe them as triggers.

Pathplanner will automatically create it once you go in pathplanner and create your first auto. To do that, look in pathplanner for the right side of the screen and hit the plus button on the right side of the screen, which takes you to the auto creation step

It is my understanding now that ALL commands that are defined on markers will not stop the bot and will run parallel to the actual driving. However, you can define various GROUPS of commands that would start at a time when you reach that marker.

I see. You mean - in order for the commands to run, I really need to create an AUTO, it’s not enough just to have a TRAJECTORY?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-22T03:18:42.419Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":39,"readers_count":38,"score":12.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496515,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":70441,"username":"SnappleBot","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands/496515/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3565177,"name":"","username":"SnappleBot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T03:20:45.697Z","cooked":"

A trajectory is just the shape and waypoints of the path, while an auto is the actual chain of paths that make the robot move in auto.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-22T03:21:41.075Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":39,"readers_count":38,"score":7.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496515,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50762,"username":"atsekhan","name":"Alex Tsekhansky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands/496515/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3565179,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T03:22:02.141Z","cooked":"

Yes, and that works even in trajectory.

We do not use zoned commands, though, as all of the ones we use really just need to run until they end (e.g. Elevator UP and ARM to certain position). It is my understanding that Zoned command is simply the one that is force-interrupted when you reach the end of the zone, even if it did not finish.

That’s possible. However, I would recommend for simplicity using names commands with pathplanner and setting it up so they start after each chunk of the path finishes i.e getting to reef and coral station and intake or score did you figure out how to make the autos?.

In our previous competitions we did individual trajectory driving on coordinates, which made the auto command complicated. So, we only did 2-coral auto. It is vision-aided, so worked fine. For district finals we see we can easily make at least 3, as long as we run things in parallel properly and safely. So, we’re trying to make a maximum use of the PP interface and drawn trajectories instead of us specifying coordinates in a dozen of different places.

And yes, to answer your question - we did see how to make an AUTO

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-22T03:30:52.777Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":34,"readers_count":33,"score":11.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496515,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands","display_username":"Alex Tsekhansky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":70441,"username":"SnappleBot","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands/496515/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3565190,"name":"","username":"SnappleBot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T03:31:09.585Z","cooked":"

If you want speed and our confident in alignment and vision , parallel commands are the way to go. You can raise the elector while you drive and then just plop it off at the reef, nice and easy!

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-22T03:31:09.585Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":33,"readers_count":32,"score":16.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496515,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50762,"username":"atsekhan","name":"Alex Tsekhansky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-markers-and-sequential-commands/496515/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3565197,"name":"Alex Tsekhansky","username":"atsekhan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/0ea827/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T03:35:47.005Z","cooked":"

Yes, that’s the plan. But we do not want to raise the elevator and drive FAST (we have SDS modules with Krakens and L4). Also our elevator is FAST by itself. So, we will define markers to raise it somewhere in a middle of the trajectory, not at the beginning, to make everything less tippy.

But we had a wrong understanding that some commands would make PP stop and wait until command it done, if it’s done on a marker. Now I see that ALL commands on event markers are always done parallel to the trajectory, and the parallel/sequential etc options are there only if you want to have multiple things triggered at the marking.

Also, there is a setting tab in pathplanner, where you can configure your robot. If you are worried about going to fast, you can lower max speed or max acceleration, in meters per second

We are using event markers with named commands in each path for elevator setpoints, etc, when we want it to react early but we end paths where we want to stop. Then combining into an auto that adds additional commands between paths.

We talked about intaking early but I think with named commands it would end with the path. I think to make that work smoothly through stopping that a Trigger would be better.

And constraint zones to set different speeds. For 3 coral were trying to limit speed last 15% or so to not slam into the reef.

We also use rotation or point to for getting our reef camera earlier as default path rotates more slowly.

Exactly. Same here - no slamming into the reef or coral station

With cameras - it’s easier for us. We have two LLs at different angles. We usually do not lose track of the Apriltags from the reef.

After the previous games we also decided to rely squarely on LL4-s. They provide insane framerate, and much better tracking. We angle them so they only look at the reef tags. For autos and teleop positioning that appears to be enough. We had a few more LL2+ before pointing to different directions, but it really only made things worse as they picked up far Apriltags and gave coordinates worse than on-board odometry calculated by the CTR swerve chassis object.
